meanings.definition: To infer or estimate by extending or projecting known information.
meanings.sent1: I can extrapolate the answer by looking at the pattern.
meanings.sent2: Scientists can extrapolate future trends based on current data.
meanings.sent3: I tried to extrapolate how many cookies I could eat in a day.
meanings.sent4: She extrapolated the growth of the plant to a flourishing relationship.
meanings.sent5: The detective had to extrapolate the suspect's whereabouts from the clues.

meanings.definition: To predict or estimate based on existing data.
meanings.sent1: Can you extrapolate the outcome of the experiment?
meanings.sent2: Economists often extrapolate market trends to make forecasts.
meanings.sent3: I tried to extrapolate how many hours of sleep I would need.
meanings.sent4: She extrapolated the success of the project to a sunny day.
meanings.sent5: The teacher had to extrapolate the students' grades from their previous performance.

meanings.definition: To extend or expand upon existing information or data.
meanings.sent1: We need to extrapolate our research to include more samples.
meanings.sent2: The report will extrapolate on the findings from the survey.
meanings.sent3: I tried to extrapolate how far I could run without stopping.
meanings.sent4: She extrapolated the story to include more characters.
meanings.sent5: The artist had to extrapolate the painting to cover the entire wall.
